stem: Which finding requires the MOST immediate action by the nurse?

rationale.correct: The patient's oxygen saturation of 88% despite supplemental oxygen indicates severe respiratory compromise requiring immediate intervention. This could be due to worsening pulmonary edema related to fluid overload from CKD, and requires immediate intervention such as increasing oxygen delivery and potentially escalating care. The reduced oxygen saturation impairs tissue oxygenation, potentially leading to organ damage and failure if not promptly addressed.

mnemonic.meaning: Airway, Breathing, Circulation - prioritize these in that order.

rationale.incorrect: While a potassium level of 6.2 mEq/L is elevated and requires treatment, the respiratory compromise poses a more immediate threat to the patient's life. Addressing the hypoxemia is the priority. Hyperkalemia can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, but the immediate threat to airway and breathing takes precedence. The blood pressure of 170/98 is elevated, but not immediately life-threatening compared to the respiratory distress. While the glucose of 180 mg/dL needs to be addressed, it is less immediately life-threatening than the respiratory distress.

questionTrap.reason: Students may prioritize lab values over clinical assessment and ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation).
questionTrap.commonMistake: Focusing solely on the elevated potassium level without considering the immediate threat of hypoxemia.

clinicalPearls: Patients with CKD are at high risk for fluid overload and pulmonary edema.
Hyperkalemia can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, but should be addressed after the airway and breathing are stabilized.

itemContext.sbar: 14:00, S: Patient is a 68-year-old male with CKD stage 4, admitted for fluid overload. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. B: He's been receiving IV furosemide 40mg q12h. He reports increased shortness of breath and orthopnea since this morning. A: Oxygen saturation is 88% on 2L nasal cannula. Increased work of breathing noted. Auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. Vitals: BP 170/98, HR 110, RR 28. Labs pending. R: Increase oxygen to 4L via nasal cannula. Obtain ABGs. Notify provider of patient's respiratory status change.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: 14:00, S: Patient is a 68-year-old male with CKD stage 4, admitted for fluid overload. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. B: He's been receiving IV furosemide 40mg q12h. He reports increased shortness of breath and orthopnea since this morning. A: Oxygen saturation is 88% on 2L nasal cannula. Increased work of breathing noted. Auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. Vitals: BP 170/98, HR 110, RR 28. Labs pending. R: Increase oxygen to 4L via nasal cannula. Obtain ABGs. Notify provider of patient's respiratory status change.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
13:55

  • BP: 170/98 mmHg
  • HR: 110 bpm
  • RR: 28 breaths/min, labored
  • SpO2: 88% on 2L NC
  • Temp: 37.2°C (99.0°F)

tabs.title: PhysicalExam
tabs.content:
13:58

  • General: Appears anxious and uncomfortable.
  • Respiratory: Increased work of breathing, bilateral crackles auscultated.
  • Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, no murmurs noted.
  • Integumentary: 2+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

tabs.title: CarePlan
tabs.content:
Current Care Plan:

  • Administer furosemide 40mg IV q12h.
  • Monitor fluid balance (I&O).
  • Assess respiratory status q4h.
  • Monitor electrolytes.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Medication Administration Record:

  • Furosemide 40mg IV - Administered at 13:00
  • Insulin sliding scale - Not administered
